description: From Middle English noen, none, non, from Old English nōn (“the ninth hour”), from a Germanic borrowing of classical Latin nōna (“ninth hour”) (short for nōna hōra), feminine of nōnus (“ninth”). Cognate with Dutch noen, obsolete German Non, Norwegian non.

entries.meaning: The time of day when the sun is in its zenith; twelve o'clock in the day, midday.
examples: On Sundays, I love to have a lie-in until noon.
The race is due to start at noon sharp.

entries.meaning: (now rare) The corresponding time in the middle of the night; midnight.
examples: So the sad mother at the noon of night / From bloody Memphis stole her silent flight  […] .

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The ninth hour of the day counted from sunrise; around three o'clock in the afternoon.

verbs.description: noon (third-person singular simple present noons, present participle nooning, simple past and past participle nooned)

entries.meaning: To relax or sleep around midday
examples: We presently turned just aside from the trail into an episode of beautiful prairie, one of a succession along the plateau at the crest of the range. At this height of about five thousand feet, the snows remain until June. In this fair, oval, forest-circled prairie of my nooning, the grass was long and succulent, as if it grew in the bed of a drained lake.

entries.meaning: The letter ن in the Arabic script.
